titleStmt.title: A Citation Verification Tool for Generative AI-Assisted Research Writing

analytic.title: A Citation Verification Tool for Generative AI-Assisted Research Writing

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a powerful tool for drafting research manuscripts. Its ability to quickly generate structured text is invaluable for researchers who may not have the time to fully document their original ideas yet want to contribute preliminary proposals to the academic community. However, a recurring issue is the generation of fabricated references that do not exist in genuine literature. This paper presents a method and accompanying API to verify the authenticity of references produced by generative AI systems. A desktop-based citation checker was implemented using Python and the OpenAlex API. The tool automates the verification of bibliographic entries from BibT E X files and provides feedback on the correctness of titles, authors, years, and sources. Experimental results and example outputs demonstrate its effectiveness in improving citation reliability. The tool offers particular value for graduate student supervisors, significantly reducing the time and effort required to ensure reference accuracy in theses and dissertations. The broader implication is the creation of a reliable assistive system for documenting novel ideas, ensuring academic integrity, and supporting intellectual development.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: The rapid adoption of generative AI in academic writing has transformed the way researchers draft articles, proposals, and reports. In many cases, AI-generated text allows scholars to quickly record original ideas, including background, methodology, implementation, and expected outcomes, even when time is limited. This early recording safeguards intellectual ownership and fosters knowledge sharing within the community.

However, a critical limitation arises: references generated by AI are frequently fabricated or mismatched. While the narrative may be coherent, citations often point to non-existent articles or incorrect bibliographic metadata. This not only undermines academic integrity but also imposes significant burdens on supervisors and reviewers who must manually verify each reference.

To address this challenge, we propose a citation verification tool that integrates with the OpenAlex API to validate bibliographic entries. The goal is to ensure that references cited in AI-assisted writing correspond to genuine, published works. This effort aligns with broader research on mitigating reliance on generative AI in education, such as the approach discussed in [1].

div.head: II. RELATED WORK
div.p: Existing tools in reference management, such as Zotero and EndNote, focus primarily on organizing legitimate references rather than detecting fabricated ones. Some plagiarism detection systems highlight inconsistencies in citations, but few are tailored to the specific problem of verifying AIgenerated references. Our approach fills this gap by providing an automated, API-driven checker that integrates seamlessly with the BibT E X ecosystem.

div.head: A. System Overview
div.p: The proposed system is a Python-based desktop application, developed using the tkinter GUI framework. Users provide a valid email and upload a .bib file containing references. The application queries the OpenAlex API with each entry's metadata and compares local fields against validated data from the database.

div.head: B. Key Features
div.p: • DOI Verification: Ensures the DOI exists in OpenAlex.

• Title Matching: Normalizes and compares titles to detect mismatches. • Author and Year Check: Confirms the accuracy of author attribution and publication year. • Source Validation: Matches the source (journal, conference, or book title) with verified metadata.

div.head: C. Implementation
div.p: The checker employs a background thread to avoid UI blocking and a queue to manage results efficiently. Results are displayed in a table format with indicators for correctness (✓ / ✕). A snapshot of the verification results illustrates discrepancies in titles, authors, years, and sources.

div.head: B. Python Implementation
div.p: The full Python code of the citation checker, including GUI and API integration, is included in Appendix A.

div.head: C. Results Snapshot
div.p: The snapshot in Figure 1 shows how the tool identifies false citations, such as incorrect years (e.g., "1998" instead of the actual "2022") and mismatched sources. These results provide strong evidence of the tool's effectiveness in automating citation verification.

div.head: V. IMPLICATIONS
div.p: The proposed tool has several key implications: 1) For Researchers: Assists in quickly validating AIassisted drafts, ensuring references are reliable before submission. 2) For Supervisors: Saves time in verifying student theses, which often contain dozens of references. 3) For Academic Integrity: Reduces the risk of fabricated references undermining scholarly trust. 4) For Knowledge Recording: Provides a safeguard for researchers documenting original ideas under time pressure, ensuring their proposals are supported with genuine references. This aligns with the goals of AI-resistant education, where tools support instructors in detecting errors or misuse of AI in student submissions [2]. Furthermore, this work contributes to the broader effort of encouraging students to produce genuine work while using AI responsibly as a learning aid, as discussed in [3].

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: Generative AI is becoming inevitable in academic writing. While it accelerates idea documentation, the issue of fabricated references remains a critical barrier to trust. This paper introduces a Python-based citation verification tool that leverages the OpenAlex API to check the authenticity of AIgenerated references. Testing with example files confirmed its effectiveness in distinguishing genuine works from fabricated entries. The tool provides practical benefits for researchers, supervisors, and the broader academic community by promoting intellectual honesty and protecting original contributions.
